signal.translation[0].definitions[0].def: a sound or an action that you make in order to give information to someone or tell them to do something
signal.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: At a prearranged signal the lights went out.
When she got up from the table, it was obviously the signal for us to leave.
signal.translation[0].definitions[1].def: an event or action that shows what someone feels, what exists, or what is likely to happen
signal.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: We don't want to give out the wrong signal to investors.
These results are a signal that the child may need special help.
The opinion poll is a clear signal of people’s dissatisfaction with the government.
the danger signals of a heart attack
signal.translation[0].definitions[2].def: a series of light waves, sound waves etc that carry an image, sound, or message, for example in radio or television
signal.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: This new pay-TV channel sends signals via satellite to cable companies.
a small antenna which can receive radio signals
The coastguard picked up a distress signal from a freighter 50 miles out at sea.
signal.translation[0].definitions[3].def: a piece of equipment with coloured lights, used on a railway to tell train drivers whether they can continue or must stop
signal.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: a signal failure (=when these lights do not work)
signal.translation[0].note_box[0].headin: – Meaning 2: an event or action that shows what someone feels, what exists, or what is likely to happen
signal.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: My body was giving me a clear signal that something was wrong.
Managers should keep a watchful eye open for the danger signals.
Reducing the penalty for marijuana use perhaps sends the wrong signal to teenagers.
Our culture gives girls mixed messages about food, with skinny models and fast-food commercials competing for attention.
The use of the army sends out a clear signal to protesters that their actions will not be tolerated.
President Nixon read the signals and decided it was time to resign.
signal.translation[0].note_box[1].headin: – Meaning 3: a series of light waves, sound waves etc that carry an image, sound, or message, for example in radio or television
signal.translation[0].note_box[1].sectio: The signals are transmitted via satellites.
The device emits a signal which can be picked up by a submarine.
The antenna that will pick up the signals is a 12-metre dish.
Copper wires carry the electrical signals.
The signal travels over the cable network.
I can’t use my phone because the signal isn’t strong enough here.
The signals were too weak for the receiver to pick up.
A transmitter connected to the door bell sends radio signals to a portable receiver.
Digital signals can be compressed to take up less space.
signal.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to make a sound or an action in order to give information or tell someone to do something
signal.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: She signalled, and the waiter brought the bill.
The whistle signalled the end of the match.
Mary signalled wildly at them, but they didn’t notice.
The judge signaled to a police officer and the man was led away.
He pushed his plate away and signalled for coffee.
She signalled to the children to come inside.
The bell signaled that school was over.
signal.translation[1].definitions[1].def: to make something clear by what you say or do – used in news reports
signal.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: Both sides have signaled their willingness to start negotiations.
British sources last night signalled their readiness to talk.
The prime minister’s speech today signals that there will be a shakeup in the cabinet.
signal.translation[1].definitions[2].def: to be a sign that something is going to happen
signal.translation[1].definitions[2].exa: the lengthening days that signal the end of winter
signal.translation[1].definitions[3].def: to show the direction you intend to turn in a vehicle, using the lights
signal.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: The university has done me the signal honour of making me an Honorary Fellow.
